posts.com:
In The Selfish Gene, Richard Dawkins proposed honest advertising as the evolutionary explanation for the loss of the baculum. The hypothesis states that if erection failure is a sensitive early warning of ill health (physical or mental), females could have gauged the health of a potential mate based on his ability to achieve erection without the support of a baculum.

The tactile stimulation hypothesis proposes that the loss of the baculum in humans is linked to the female choice for tactile stimulation: a boneless penis would be more flexible, facilitating a larger range of copulatory positions and whole body movement, giving females greater general physical stimulation.

The mating system shift hypothesis proposes that the shift towards monogamy as the dominant reproductive strategy may have reduced the intensity of copulatory and post-copulatory sexual selection, and made the baculum obsolete.

Humans "evolved a mating system in which the male tended to accompany a particular female all the time to try to ensure paternity of her children" which allows for frequent matings of short duration. Observation suggests that primates with a baculum only infrequently encounter females, but engage in longer periods of copulation that the baculum makes possible, thereby maximizing their chances of fathering the female's offspring. Human females exhibit concealed ovulation, also known as hidden estrus, meaning it is almost impossible to tell when the female is fertile, so frequent matings would be necessary to ensure paternity.

Not everyone knows or is totally convinced of discipline's utility to them. Discipline for discipline's sake, or out of a sense of vague obligation to yourself, is extremely difficult to build. Without a direction that your heart and mind are both set on, building discipline is just more meaningless suffering. A foundational part of self mastery is finding what meaningful goal lies on the journey or at the end, so that you can apply yourself fully.

>What would you do in my shoes?
First and foremost, get off the computer and out into public. The computer ain't gonna teach you social skills, people watching can at least give you a hint about interpersonal interactions and it will get your feet wet about the social anxiety. People feel uncomfortable if they receive unsolicited scrutiny, so make sure you invent a reason to be out watching people like you're enjoying the weather or waiting on someone.
Going to the gym will expose you to a sample of the public and help fix your obesity.
>Scared to drive long distances by myself
Why are you scared? Falling asleep at the wheel? Breaking down somewhere? If you feel this inability is truly crippling, take a scooter or bike with you on a bus when you go traveling or fork out the cash for a taxi. I've found that listening to music makes the ride much shorter than it seems. I moved >150 miles away from home, which sounds kinda daunting, but it's literally just three hourlong music mixes.
>Live with parents in a tiny town in the middle of nowhere
Move out, even if it's for a year or two in an apartment. The sooner you taste freedom, the sooner you taste loneliness, the sooner you begin to truly value social interactions. If you don't taste the artificial loneliness to steel yourself, you're going to have a rough time when you're parents pass away and you really are alone.

The male-female ratio is tilted and gives women an even bigger edge, if they can put up with all the "Hey"s and unsolicited dick pics. I remember someone on here a while ago saying they were with one of the apps and that the algorithm is designed to give a new profile high exposure for a bit before it sinks into the masses. Every time you fork out cash, the algorithm puts the profile back towards the top. If you don't pay, the trick is to ignore the app for a while, and when it sees activity again, it tries to lure you back in by bumping the profile up again with higher odds that a sudden hit will make you want to split with more cash. Ever since I met the girl in >>27944121, I've been back to the app twice and both times, I magically got a like within a half hour, despite weeks-long dry spells while actively searching.
Unless you're hot or rich, your odds are roughly the same in all dating apps, with minor nuances in the types of people frequenting the apps.

>>27938136
I have genital herpes in the vaginal area.
It's literally a non-issue.

I freaked out at first because I was scared that my (very new) boyfriend was gonna dump me. But I'm not a slimy, cowardly piece of shit, so I bit the bullet and told him immediately. I basically told him what it meant, apologised for the bad news, encouraged him to get tested, and told him "this is a permanent thing, so I understand if you're no longer interested in dating me."
He must have been interested, because he tested negative, then he stuck around for the next 3 years.

At first I was paranoid about having sex because I didn't want him to catch it, and I always felt a little guilty afterwards. For the first few weeks, I always double-checked that he really WANTED to have sex, before proceeding. I didn't do this verbally every time lol, but I'd sort of pull away and let him lead. If he was enthusiastic about it, I took it for consent and acceptance of the risk. When he didn't get sick, I stopped being paranoid, though I did make him get yearly blood tests, just for my own peace of mind. During that entire relationship, he never caught it. Lucky bastard was one of the few people who are immune to that shit.

In 10 years, I have never had another outbreak. I haven't even had an ITCH.
Herpes is only really an issue if you're dating an immunocompromised person, because it can fuck them up. But for the majority of people, you get one shitty outbreak, then you're fine.

IME, people don't really judge you for it. I haven't dated since that last guy, but a few male friends have hit on me at some point in time, knowing damn well that I've got herpes. So obviously people aren't bothered by it.

Some people will of course reject you for it. But as long as you're cool about it, and informative and respectful, most people will be willing to date you.
You're ok, man. Don't stress. Trust me - it's not the death sentence you think it is.

>>27944400
It does eventually get easier when you un-NEET yourself and practice more consistently socially. Working in a pub can be nice (though a bit stressful), there's often a good camaraderie with your co-workers. Working in a small shop can also be really nice and you get to practice making a bit of a small-talk with all kinds of people. I work as a receptionist, I'm actually really shy but I'm able to get into "work mode" and have wholesome interactions with people and a laugh with my co-workers, and it's made me a bit more socially confident and competent in general life.
>Is there anything I shouldn't say?
Just be careful with flirting or being too syrupy sweet to guys you're not really interested in because some take it the wrong way and are persistent (though sometimes it can't be avoided, some guys seem to think just smiling at them is a signal). But at the end of the day we're just people, there are no special rules to talking to us. As a girl you have the advantage that traditionally the guy makes the first move, but don't be shy about suggesting to do something you really like.
It's overwhelming at first and you'll have days where you want to just disappear, but stick with things and try to praise yourself for your efforts, you will inevitably make progress.

>>27944226
Really depends on what you want.

For me I figure my time was valuable so I made a point to get a house right next to my work and in the opposite direction of traffic flow to further avoid rush hour traffic. It cost me a little more and I had to settle on a smaller place (it's very small compared to most, but bigger than I need), but it saves me two hours a day and reduces my car use so much that I have should start driving on the weekends to help keep my car healthy (drive 3 miles a day is bad for most cars give start stop without turning over the fluids)

My Father got our house on State emergency routes, so growing up we were always first to get snow plows, power and water restored, etc. Police, Fie and Hospital were nearby. So just about any emergency we were the first to get service, he is a little paranoid so those things were important to him.

Outside of your choices, budget and lifestyle I would say to look for lacking water damage and general build quality are important, there are things to look for but it takes some skill to notice. And inspection and some crash course Youtube helps. Cosmetic stuff like bad paint or carpet may look bad but can be fixed fairly easy with some time and money so don't overvalue those like most people. Also asbestos was banned in July 12, 1989 in the US and lead was in 1978, so any house after late 1989 is required to not have a bunch of those hazards. So I tend to like ones built in the 1990's as it is after most bad stuff was banned but before builders got super cheap, but that's a trend not a rule so you still have to do your research. Look out for DIY, that tends to have extreme results as you either get someone who knows and cares which is great or an idiot who made the place an accident waiting to happen. Also take note of appliances and finishes, if you noticed they are too cheap then the owner likely may have skipped other investments that you'll have to pay for.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27944809
I’m from the US so your mileage may vary on this, but I’ll tell you what I’ve learned from doing the opposite of what you’re doing (grew up country, had to move to the city for school).

The singular greatest thing about the country is freedom. You want to go buck naked onto your front porch and take a morning piss? Nobody’s there to stop you. Want to shoot squirrels from the back porch and learn how to make them into a nice stew? Have at it. Pretty much the only three rules that are enforced out in the sticks are: Don’t steal, don’t hurt other people, and don’t go on somebody else’s property. So long as you don’t do it in front of the lone cop in the county nobody really cares about the rest.

Next is country people. As the last detail might have implied they are a very ‘live and let live’ kind of people so long as they don’t feel like you’re trying to force your city ideals on them. These people also party like you wouldn’t believe. I’d kill to have a bonfire out in the woods with the boys again.

Lastly, at least where I was, you don’t have to wait in line for practically anything. If there’s more than four cars in the McDonalds drive through it’s a busy day for them. There’s only two restaurants in town where you have to wait on a table, and that’s only on Friday/Saturday nights. Lastly, any type of service you need, plumbing, heating, electrical, are only booked a day or two out at most. And everything costs less, to boot.

In short, make friends who’ll introduce you to country life and how it’s supposed to be done. Take advantage of the benefits country life has to offer instead of wishing it was more like the city, or else you’re going to be miserable.

This is going to sound brutal, cos I'm condensing into a few paragraphs what a therapist would take months to explain, but the format requires it, so:

Your problem is, you've given up.

There are many things you could do to improve your life, but you've already looked at them and decided they're all impossible.

If you want life to be better, you have to make two changes to the way you think:

1) Stop thinking about what you "can't" do and start thinking about what you MUST do.

2) Every time you encounter an obstacle, instead of giving up, say to yourself "Okay, what am I going to do about that?"

It's pretty obvious to me that the most important thing you need to do is leave your husband. Husbands are supposed to support you and strengthen you. Your husband isn't a partner, he's a parasite, sucking all the strength and ultimately the life out of your body. Leaving him won't be easy, but the alternative is to stay trapped a life that is making you indescribably miserable, smoking illegal drugs while pregnant and giving your baby brain damage. That's not sustainable.

So, stop thinking in terms of "I can't leave him" and start thinking "I MUST leave him"; and for each difficulty that then comes up, ask "Okay, what am I going to do about that?"

You can't get to a job without a car? Okay, what are you going to do about that? Are there buses? Could you use the money than you earn from a job to actually buy a car?

Childcare is a problem? Okay, what are you going to do about that? Do you have friends and family who could help out? Could you get a job that has an office crèche? Is there a college nearby where there are students who are desperate to make a little money babysitting? Could you get a job near a daycare centre? There are all kinds of possibilities you aren't exploring because it's so much easier to give up.

I'm sure you can think of a thousand other problems, but in response to every single one I will say "What are you going to do about that?'

>>27942200
I can't say it all in a post but I'll try. Firstly, you most likely have depression, which is warping how you perceive everything. If you are depressed, you don't realise your perception is being warped because depressed people always think they are extremely logical and objective. This is in fact an anti-cope, they have to believe this or the whole description of reality created by the depressed mind comes crashing down. So your first priority is ameliorating your depression. You can talk to a doctor, try some pills if you're up for it. Personally I found cognitive behavioural therapy the most useful approach in the long run. This can be with a therapist but there are also many books on this.
Secondly, sex has a special status in our culrure now, but on a biological level it's just a form of socialising, part of a spectrum of social activities of varying intimacy that humans naturally do. You can already socialise, we are socialising right now in a limited way. The more you socialise, the more you form relationships with people, the more likely it is that you will at some point have sex. I know you imagine that only the especially attractive or charismatic can have sex but this is objectively not true. Average guys have sex, fat guys have sex, even ugly guys have sex.

Work on your depression, work on socialising. Note that these are both long term projects.

>I am old (turning 25 soon)
Couple of things. First, while “old” is relative, you’ll be hard pressed to find anyone outside of grade school who thinks 25 is “old”, even for a woman.

Second, you’re allowing yourself to ruin your own life. An average woman of 25 today can expect to live to about 90 on average. Do you really think women past their early 20’s are just damned to be miserable for the vast bulk of their lives? It’s okay to mourn your youth- most people do. But then you move on and realize that there was a lot of bullshit and stupidity in your youth that you no longer have to put up with. Not to mention you now control your own fate. Being an object of attraction shouldn’t even be that life defining for you. If it is, it means you haven’t even begun to experience self-actualization. If your only value in life is attraction, you have no real value and you are completely subject to whims of others.

Third, if you ARE physically undesirable at 25, it means you were always physically undesirable. Those couple of years are not enough to make that dramatic of a difference.

Lastly, you could a body image disorder, akin to anorexia. If that’s the case, the problem is simply due to a chemical imbalance or synapse structural issue in the brain. This can and must be treated.

P.S. Have you never heard of MILFs? Hell, some guys are even into GILFs. Maybe you don’t like the way you look, but that doesn’t meant everyone else feels the same.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27944144
It depends on the severity, and whether it is an anxiety attack or true panic attack. Anxiety attacks are miserable, but panic attacks have physical symptoms that tend feel like you are actually dying.

If it’s making your life miserable, but you are still functioning, there are some exercises you can do on your own to help. Look both for what you can do during the attack (such as breathing through a couple of straws and focusing on that as much as you can) and for what you can do to reduce the number and severity of the attacks (mindful meditation, except that improves heart rate variability, etc)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>> I have been through only one breakup, and the feeling is not unlike that

After 3 days and zero dates? Wow dude, for starters you're way to clingy. Sort that shit out.

>> talking for less than 3 or so days

You've been talking for 3 or so days straight. You're overselling and giving away too much too quickly without the benefit of shared experience to bond you. Of course they lose interest. You want her number to call her. You call her to secure a date in the near future (same week). Other than to let her know you're running late or alternating plans you don't contact her before the date.

All of the getting to know each other happens in person, whilst doing something. It has a point where the date ends. You secure another date before you leave. The only time you contact her between dates is to

* Secure another date
* Reinforce you had a nice time (only do this once)
* Discuss where a date might be
* Let her know you're running late or need to alter something.

Her interest in you is then tied to shared experiences and what you give away is limited so the mystery continues longer. After 3-5 dates and you're still both interested you can start to have more conversations over the phone/text but be cautious still not to give too much too quickly or interfere with the anticipation of the next date. Keep that going until things naturally progress from dating to a relationship.

Move mountains to not be late on dates. Definitely don't be chronically late.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27941983
Its already the TLDR, but if you insist. You must have experienced ambivalence regarding porn addiction. One the one hand you desperately want to quit, on the other you want to keep using.

The side that wants to quit is the real you. This is your neocortex, your thinking, deliberating, rational side. The "real" YOU. The other side is the Addictive Voice (AV), the "primal" midbrain.

The midbrain is a primal part of your brain that regulates breathing and basic survival instincts I think. Like to ensure that whatever you may be thinking, atleast you will be motivated to eat. And just like breathing and eating the midbrain has been conditioned to see pornography as just as important.

The midbrain has no real direct power over you. It cant order you to do anything. It is however a master in seduction so it will use your brains language, imagination centres etc to tempt you to use. Think flashing imagery, or it will try to get you into a negative argumental spiral. The AV comes from the midbrain.

We want to stop letting the midbrain run the show. So we identify its spokesperson, the AV. We learn how it operates, what it can do and how we should counter it.

By learning to fight against the AV we shut it up and thus solve ambivalence. With no ambivalence in place we suddenly find we can say no and just continue with our day.

In other words, we will start a boxing match every time the midbrain wants to, except we already knocked out our opponent when he leaves his house, let alone the ring.

Let me know if this makes sense.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27941343
>>I wonder if engineers are safe though...
As a biased programmer, I'd still predict they will be for at least the next 5 or so years. Two big reasons.

First and biggest, at least for now GPT copilot-style coding is really, really bad at brownfield development. When you've got a codebase that's been around for 5-20 years and it's still being used, AI is bad at making useful modifications to your existing garbage fire, you still seem to need a human for that. Not like
>A human to drive the AI
but just a human, straight up, because the AI doesn't even know where to begin. For most current existing non-startup work-streams, this makes AI coding almost useless immediately.

Second, because code it outputs needs to be consumed by human readers, and the AI outputs are unacceptably ugly as part of a human work-stream when the AI is unacceptably bad at explaining its work.

Even when the code works, AI solutions tend to look like Yandere Simulator meme screenshots, most of the training data seems to have been bottom of the barrel copy-paste monkeys who didn't know what they were doing either. Unoptimized output, useless variable names, no comments, awful structure, and no adherence to consistent styling. People like to joke
>haha just like programmers amirite upvotes to the left
But one of the biggest problems slowing companies is
>no one understands that part of the code, the dev was garbage, it's undocumented, and now they've fucked off to another company and we're screwed because no one understands the code
And that's basically the only kind of code that AI currently knows how to write. At its current level, using AI on a good day is like hiring bad outsourcers - you get brittle 100% unmaintainable code that "technically works (for now)"

It's not impossible these will be resolved, and for greenfield work like startups, it being fast will reduce early company roles - but at established devshops, at best it's a rare "sometimes" productivity enhancer.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27937936
It's an evolutionary tactic to avoid letting autists breed lol.

Fr though, we flirt for a reason.
We're social animals. We need other people. We need to be liked. We have an innate desire to be accepted by others.
Hints allow us to communicate our potentially risky or unacceptable ideas, with the lowered likelihood of being outright rejected and possibly ostracised by the crowd. Ironically, they help us to 'be ourselves' around others in a safer way.

Think of it this way: if you hate the joos, you're probably not gonna stand on a table an heil hitler at work. You'll get fucking fired.
Instead, you make jokes and hint subtly that you hate the joos while talking shit with your coworkers. Then you look around to see whether any of your coworkers have that sparkle of a true Brother in their eyes. Then you know that you can talk outright with that coworker about how much you hate jews, because you know it's safe.

Flirting is similar.
It feels bad to be rejected. It can be socially damaging to be outright rejected. It can fuck your self-esteem up to get rejected. So you flirt to hint that you like the person, and if you notice them flirting back, you go ahead and ask them on a date. If they don't flirt back, you know you've been rejected, but the sting is less painful, and you're not embarrassed by the failure.

I know it sounds retarded, but that's just how this shit works. We're social creatures. It's important to learn how to understand one another via gestures and hints. It's just how we function.

I understand why you're frustrated over it. But it's just one of those things that you're gonna have to get good at, because it's not going away.
You gotta learn this skill, man. If you really struggle with this shit, get into therapy or something and ask for help navigating social situations and flirting. It's a necessary skill for life.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I don't have much love for the Christmas gift-giving ritual because, for most of my childhood people, people ignored when I talked about what I wanted and just bought a cheap off-brand of whatever they thought I wanted (or what my brother wanted, in twos) a majority of the time. Eventually, I just stopped asking and tried to be gracious with what I got.
I'm poor. I don't have much money. I'm practically unemployable atm. The year before last, I didn't have money to get anyone anything, and I was embarrassed to receive even the unfitting gifts I did get (mostly clothes). Last year, I wanted to make up for it, and went a thousand or so dollars into debt trying to get meaningful things for people (also spent a lot of time and energy trying to deal with a package that got stolen off the porch, and hand-knitting a blanket for my sister and sister-in-law). This year, I again have pretty much no money (due to some dumb /biz/-related decisions). I was going to just explicitly ask for no presents this year and not buy anything, but my sister hounded me to sign up for Giftster. So, I bought a piece each, dipping into my "Don't Lose My Storage Unit Filled With Irreplaceable Possessions" fund, and made a modest list of things that I'd genuinely enjoy and use. At least, I thought, there would be no way to fuck up wrt what I wanted.
Today, I got a call from my mom asking to come up with a replacement for a particular item because it would arrive too late. I said that I didn't mind, and she kind of hemmed and hawed and suggested looking on Amazon anyway "because of the shipping." I looked it up again. Shipping is free and the thing is on sale.
It just kind of sucked all the enthusiasm out of me. I'm not sure what to think or do. First world problems, w/e.

Realize that your crush is a person going through their own shit and there are thousands of reasons they could have rejected you that have nothing to do with you as a person.
Take pride in the fact you actually had the balls to make a pass at them, and at least now you won't waste emotional energy on something that's never going to happen.
Put yourself in a position to meet new people, there are a lot of potential partners out there and many of them will be a better match than your crush.
It's normal to feel sad and disappointed after being rejected, but it's something that everyone has to face and learn to move on from.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27941533
>I want to make AI that predicts crime
In practice, for crime prediction, you don't need a college education if you want to do this, there's basically only two ways this plays out.

Either you're going to use """AI""" without needing to understand any of the underpinnings because the plan is to throw gradient descent at a pile of normalized data and hope it shits out useful information, which won't work today because there ISN'T such a data pile and 99.9999999% of the work of this project would be building scraped data ingestion automation pipelines and data cleaning, since all of the police departments you care about are going to expose differing data sets and will be doing their own shit completely differently, and none of them collaborate or care about interoperability

OR you're just gonna forward predict on old values with numeric methods like polynomial regressions, which you can easily do in excel (which is what the bureaucrats to whom you'd want to sell this model are already doing anyways).

If this genuinely is you goal, there's no class for it, save yourself the money, go read the documentation for a scraper like python's BeautifulSoup, and welcome to dirty data hell because you're going to be spending the next 4-6 years building custom scrapers for every police department in your state then giving up when you realize none of their data's interoperable, financial firms have already done this work and likely aren't interested in buying your aggregations, and that governments just wanted the excel model anyways because they just wanted quick and dirty numbers since crime is primarily a problem of budgeting and political will, not one of "lack of data".

I don't have good reason to believe that my mom is gonna die anytime soon. She's fifty, eats well, exercises everyday, and has good relationships with everyone. The most dangerous things she does is drive to and from work on mildly busy streets on weekdays and sleeps mediocrely. However, I haven't yet been able to convince myself that I shouldn't feel vulnerable to the possibility of her dying regardless of how slim the chance is.
I'm a dependent. I've been taking care of the house and her daughter/my little sister in exchange for my mom letting me live here. We all care for each other; my mom and I are good friends. If my mom were to die, I'm convinced life would suck dick. I have sparse work experience. I don't have a job, a car, or much money. If I'm were able to get a job after her death, it'd probably be an immediate shitty one. My sister would have to move in with her aunt and uncle, so my mom dying would mean I lose two people I care about.
I'd like to make steps to alleviate my vulnerability and become independent while still being happy, but I don't know where I'm going in my life. I got an associate's in general transfer studies from a community college a year ago, and I was thinking of using that to pursue a career in psychology/philosophy, but I'm not sure. I worry about what would happen if my mom were to die while I'm in pursuit of a higher up degree. I was thinking maybe joining the military would be an immediate solution, but I worry about what'd happen to the family house.
This is a fear I have to come to terms with wherever I decide to go, and I've been letting it be something that keeps me stagnant. Any ideas that'd help me move on with my life? How do you NEETs living with family out there not worry about it?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27942817
Answer generated by ChatGPT.

It's completely normal to feel vulnerable and uncertain about the future, especially when it comes to the well-being of a loved one. It's understandable that you're worried about what would happen if your mom were to pass away, especially since you're currently dependent on her for housing and support. However, it's important to remember that worrying about something that may or may not happen in the future can be unproductive and can even hinder your ability to move forward and make positive changes in your life.

One way to cope with these fears is to focus on the things that you can control. For example, you can take steps to become more independent and self-sufficient, such as seeking out job opportunities and building your work experience, saving money, and developing skills that will be useful in the future. It may also be helpful to have a plan in place for what you would do if your mom were to pass away, even if it's just a rough outline. Having a plan can give you a sense of control and can help you feel more prepared to handle any challenges that may arise.

Another way to cope with your fears is to reach out to others for support. This could be a close friend or family member who you can talk to about your worries, or a therapist who can help you work through your feelings and develop strategies for managing them. It may also be helpful to connect with others who are in a similar situation, whether through online support groups or in-person meetups.

Ultimately, it's important to try to focus on the present moment and the things that you can control, rather than worrying excessively about the future. While it's natural to have concerns and fears, it's important to find ways to manage them and to take steps to build a fulfilling and independent life for yourself.
